captions.text:
Cleaning the interior of my car
is as important to me as

the exterior, because when I'm
with my car, I'm mostly inside
behind the wheel.

I want the cabin to look, smell,
and, more importantly,
feel clean.

For today's interior detailing
episode, we're going to cover
a variety of techniques.

Some are very basic and easy and
can be done for under $20,

while other techniques are more
advanced and will require
additional cleaning tools.

We're going to go over a lot
of information today, so be

sure and check out ammonyc.com
for a free a downloadable PDF

with a listing of these
step-by-step instructions.

Having the right tools is key
to doing an interior detail.

On this side here, we have
microfiber towels.

We have brushes and, of course,
a few products.

This would be considered the
weekend warrior side of the
detailing tools.

Over here, we have
our professional.

We have big, heavy vacuums,
ozone machines.

We have Porter cables with
brushes on them, steam

machines, and hot
water extractor.

Whatever tool fits your budget,
time, and the amount

of cars and condition that
you're working with, these are

all great options for your
interior detailing.

Once all miscellaneous items are
removed from the interior,

the first and most basic
technique for cleaning

leather, plastics, and vinyl is
with a designated interior

cleaner and a microfiber
towel.

Apply a few squirts to a
clean microfiber towel.

Then wipe away the dirt
with medium pressure.

In some cases, this may be
enough to clean the material
you're working.

However, this Lexus requires
another few steps because of
its heavy dirt and grime.

For step two, add your interior
cleanser to a soft

bristle brush and agitate until
foamy lather is created.

Unlike painted surfaces, circles
can be used on leather
with your interior brush.

Don't allow the cleaner to dry
on the surface, as the dirt is

suspended within the lather
you've created.

Immediately wipe with
a microfiber tower.

After step two, most interiors
are back in shape.

But in rare cases, technique
three may be required.

Although this section of the
side bolster looks much

better, there are small areas
that need a little extra help.

For technique three, apply two
squirts of your cleaner to an

interior scrub pad with light
pressure, and in straight

lines, work the remaining
blemish until the surface is
perfectly clean.

Remember to avoid pushing too
hard and be aware of old and

brittle surfaces, as this is
an aggressive cleaning

technique reserved for
difficult stains.

Much like paint, always work
your way up from the least

aggressive technique until you
find the method that works

best on that particular
staining or material.

When cleaning most steering
wheels, I prefer to use the

interior brush on wrapped
leather because of the exposed

stitching that is easily
cleaned with the
hairs of the brush.

Work in small areas to avoid
premature drying, and use a

microfiber towel to grip the
wheel and wipe it clean.

It's common for the steering
wheel to feel slightly sticky

after it's been cleaned because
the dirt and oils from

the driver's hands have been
removed, leaving behind a
clean, non-greasy texture.

When dust accumulates on the
dashboard, simply add two

squirts of the interior cleaner
and wipe with a
microfiber towel.

In most cases, using a brush or
a scrub pad is unnecessary.

Much like the steering wheel,
the armrest contains the most
body oils and sweat.

In this example, I used all
three techniques to show what

can be achieved after just a
few minutes of carefully

lifting and removing embedded
dirt and oils.

Besides the obvious color change
from dirty to clean,

notice the difference
in sheen.

The clean side has a natural
matte finish, while the dirty

has a shiny or light-reflective
quality

that's common on greasy
surfaces.

If you have access to a steamer,
it can be extremely

helpful on center consoles, cup
holders, and plastic seams

because of the 65 to 70
psi it creates with
low residual water.

A simple microfiber towel, along
with your brush, is also

an effective method for cleaning
around buttons,

shifter booths, and
cup holders if
don't have a steamer.

Headliners can be tricky to
clean because they are thinner

and generally the most delicate
material used on the
interior of the car.

Avoid oversoaking the headliner,
as it can cause the

fabric to sag by loosening
the glue.

Directly apply the cleaner to a
brush or a microfiber towel
before attempting to clean it.

The goal is to lift the stain
without tearing the liner or
disturbing the fibers.

Lightly blot the stain, then
comb the fibers to help blend

in the clean area with the
surrounding liner so it
doesn't stand out.

Make sure to take your time on
the driver's side door, as it

typically accumulates
heavy dirt and oil
from constant use.

All three techniques may need
to be used on the various

surfaces that makes
the door panel.

The door jam kick panels tend
to be a harder plastic, so I

like to use technique three and
scrub with firm pressure

to remove the common shoe scuffs
from getting in and out
of the car.

If you're a professional,
high-volume shop, or simply

love power tools, you can
convert a basic dual-action

polisher to an interior
scrub machine.

This brush is designed for
leather because it's soft yet
effective at lifting dirt.

Add a few squirts to the brush
and the area being cleaned.

Notice I didn't oversaturate
the seat because of the

perforations built
into the leather.

Add more cleaner as the area
needs it and work the machine

in a crisscross pattern
to effectively
covers the entire area.

Wipe clean with the
microfiber towel.

For the deepest clean, I use
a steam machine with a

microfiber towel wrapped
around the wand.

Step one is to heat the surface
to open the pores of

the leather while removing the
top layer of heavy dirt.

While it's still hot, step two
is to directly apply interior

cleaner and agitate with
your interior brush.

You can also use the scrub
pad if necessary.

This technique is highly
effective for deep cleaning

and bacteria removal, especially
for abnormally

dirty seats and when
mold is present.

Once all the leather is cleaned
and the pores of the

hide opened, it's essential to
moisturize or condition the

material to avoid stress
cracking or drying out.

Be sure to remove the excess
residue for a matte finish.

Cleaning cloth and carpet
can be tricky.

Here are a few different
techniques that you can use it

based on the level of dirt,
your comfort level, and
machines you may own.

No one method is always best,
so use the one you're most
comfortable with.

For the first technique,
presoak the
carpet with fabric cleaner.

Then use the steamer
and scrubber nozzle
to heat up the fibers.

Once heated, reapply another
round of fabric cleaner and
scrub with a carpet brush.

Finally, soak up with a clean
microfiber towel.

If you don't have any
machines, that's OK.

Much can be accomplished with a
simple bucket of hot water,

carpet brush, and a
fabric cleaner.

Liberally apply your cleaner,
then scrub in opposing
directions with firm pressure.

Once the dirt is lifted, wipe
clean with a microfiber towel.

For a professional deep clean,
a hot-water extractor is a

fantastic option because it
removes the loosened soils

immediately without the need of
additional an wet-vac step.

I use a crisscross pattern to
ensure every fiber is heat

treated from two different
angles so
that nothing is missed.

Once all carpets are cleaned,
I like to follow up with a
final vacuum.

Afterwards, I install carpet
stripes for a fresh new car
look and feel.

Start by brushing all the
fibers in one direction.

Then use the width of the brush
to point the pile in

opposing directions, giving
the illusion of stripes.

When I'm doing my final
checkover, I like to bring my

vacuum along with me to think of
anything I may have missed
in the previous steps.

Be sure to pull open seat jams
and vacuum out seat tracks,

all the while visually
inspecting your work for

stains that may have reappeared
as they dried,
which is not uncommon.

OK, we've reviewed a variety
of techniques and showed a

range of tools that I've used
as a professional detailer.

But at the end, use the
techniques that work for you

in your situation and enjoy the
satisfaction that comes

from driving in a meticulously
clean interior cabin.

For a downloadable PDF of
these steps, check out
ammonyc.com.
That's it for me, guys.

Thanks for watching another
episode of "Drive Clean" right
here on DRIVE network.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

title: Interior Detailing: Tools, Techniques, and Materials -- /DRIVE CLEAN

comments.text:
+Cam Mims I started with Meguiars myself. It is quite good and the results 
have been excellent but you have to read reviews on what products to get. 
autogeek net is a good resource.
I will admit I have not done polishing myself.
I would invest in a quality wax, but quality does not necessarily mean 
spending tons of money, because waxes get expensive fast. Something like 
wolfgangs for protectant is the most Ill spend, although here larry is 
selling his stuff too and it should be great, ive been itching to try out 
his fabric and wheel cleaner.

I will just say that what and how you do it is more important than what 
products you use, as long as you stay away from shit like armorall and the 
likes.
Get a wheel brush that fits your wheels nicely. Get a few interior brushes 
(ive impovised too) and lots of decent microfiber towels.

I used to own some kinda crappy cars and although I'd always keep them 
really clean, actual detailing was the last on my list of interests or 
likes... now owning a relatively expensive car, it is really nice to work 
on the car to maintain it and learning techniques to do it.

comments.author: Cam Mims

comments.text:
lol damn...

It is because detailing as a profession has no industry standards. so it is 
super hard to find an actual detailer and one that is good. it is all word 
of mouth and reviews.

I've found everybody from a chronic methamphetamine addict to your 
california chicken farmer pedro claiming to be detailers, and as 
enthusiastic as they might seem to do their job to earn a quick buck, the 
results are questionable.

Never attempted to try those questionable services.
Detailing takes lots of time first and foremost; it requires certain amount 
of skill and experience along with a good, meticulous eye (also, don't 
forget equipment and its proper use) and that combination does not come for 
cheap.
What I can, I do myself and I've actually found to enjoy it greatly on a 
good car, worth spending time on.

comments.text: How do I get rid of a 'old car' smell if you know what I mean~1997 BMW 528i﻿
comments.author: Naseer Syed

comments.text:
+Naseer Syed Use some deodorizer, and if you plan on shampooing the seats 
and carpet DO NOT use to much water and soak the seat foam or insulating 
pad of the carpet. I use a good carpet cleaner in a spray bottle and scrub 
with a brush then wipe dry with a micro fiber and avoid using water if I 
can..a steam cleaner will be great for the job, Also look into using a 
Ozone machine.. Also since its a BMW try replacing the cabin air cleaner, 
and assuming you have a 5 series with a sun roof make sure the sun roof 
drip rails are free from clogs and water is not over flowing some place 
else and soaking into the carpets during heavy rains. 7 Series cars are 
notorious for water running into the glove box and soaking the passenger 
carpet. Once you get the carpet soaked, it has dried getting the old funky 
smell out is quite the chore to be 100%
comments.author: EVERYDAY-XJ.COM

comments.text:
Also, you may see people use Ozone machines to get rid of some smells. You 
can get this same effect, granted not as powerful, with a product called 
Ozium (
http://www.amazon.com/OZIUM-SANITIZER-OZM-1-ORIGINAL-SCENT/dp/B000CSWCAG). 
Just spray it in the car and let it go to work. This will help AFTER you 
deep clean the carpets and interior.
comments.author: Greg Van Gorp

comments.text:
+Naseer Syed buy one of those volcanic rock packs that absorb smells and 
leave it under the seat.

comments.text:
Remove your floormats.  Cut thin rubber (like big innertubes) to fit your 
trunk, footwells and plastic door sill covers.  Apply velcro tabs and 
install in trunk and footwells, use thin 2-sided foam tape for trunk and 
door sills..  Put floormats (that you have cleaned obviously) from the 
junkyard in your car.  Remove the floormats and footwell rubber 3-4 times 
per year and clean your carpets.  When you go to sell your car, your trunk, 
footwells and floormats are pristine.﻿

But to answer your badly exaggerated question, Yes, he would be as much of 
a car guy. If someone is interested in cars then they're a car guy.

The Japanese culture is a perfect example. Drifting is the cheapest motor 
sport over there, buying a cheap second hand car and throwing it around 
like nobodies business is a lot of fun, but what would be the point of 
detailing a car like that? Does it make him less of a car guy because his 
bumper fitments consists of a rough ziptie job and mis-matched panels? No, 
it doesn't.

comments.author: Tyler Jacob

comments.text:
Instead of using scrub pad on the leather seats (I cringe at the sound of 
the scrub pad rubbing on leather).....another option which I love is to 
VERY VERY LIGHTLY swipe a Magic Eraser over the leather. Minimal pressure, 
and no hard scrubbing. Works well with only water. Fantastically effective 
and economical. ﻿
comments.author: JK Low

comments.text:
a magic eraser has the abrasiveness of sand paper. The scrub pad is way 
less aggressive. I do not recommend using a magic eraser on anything but 
hard non-painted surfaces
comments.author: Bob Havati

comments.text:
Excellent video. Thanks. 
Your interior always look much less dirty while parked indoors or in the 
shade. If weather permits, check the interior out in the open and do your 
cleaning under bright sunlight. 

For me, in my climate, I like to sit inside the vehicle with a/c on, under 
bright sunlight and start cleaning the windscreen first, followed by 
dashboard and all the little buttons. With bright sunlight, you'll see 
everything and do an excellent job. 

Once the entire dash and centre console are done, and entire floor area 
vacuumed under bright sunlight, i'll memorize all the other stained areas 
and continue cleaning in the shade or the garage. ﻿
comments.author: JK Low

comments.text:
12:40 (door jamb's kick panels). If you need to be aggresive, pls try the 
Magic Eraser pad or equivalent with water. Even more aggresive, you can try 
soaking it with Goo Gone as GG will easily remove rubber-based stains (shoe 
scrape marks). Being citrus-based, GG will never harm the plastic's colour. 
Alternatively, soak the plastic kick panel with WD40 for 5minutes and wipe 
off with a rag soaked with APC and rinse with lots of water. ﻿
comments.author: JK Low

comments.author: Matthew Sharpe

comments.text: +24AnVRodri I only had to fill mine once when I did my truck.
comments.author: White03T4RV82WD

comments.text:
yep. I used one on my 2003 4Runner after I bought it (they pretty much 
covered up the stains).I went to whole 9 years and took out the seats and 
did them by themselves to get the sides and under them. Came out looking 
brand new, and I also bought a thing of carpet cleaner when I rented it 
since I didn't have any. It if fairly strong stuff, so be sure to follow 
the directions closely.
comments.author: White03T4RV82WD

comments.text:
Yes!  I started my auto detailing with a rug doctor that I bought for $200 
on CL.   Only downside is that you have to keep refilling with hot water. 
Once I made enough money I saved to get a Mytee Lite II.  Spray chemical, 
 agitate with brush, finish with rug doctor.

comments.text:

and use a stiff brush and lift the stain. Trust me it works.

comments.text:

with faux materials.

comments.text:
Can a PC with the same brush attachment used on the leather be used on 
carpet floor mats and interior carpet?﻿
comments.author: Nickhead87

comments.text:
It will but remember leather is fragile. Using the same brush on both 
increases risk of the brush getting something caught on bristles and then 
scratch your leather if you use them at same time.
